DOC.HEAD: Many Scroogy Shoppers in Britain's Stores
DOC.TEXT: Britain's 15 percent interest rates are discouraging shoppers from splurging on Christmas gifts and threatening the country's retailers with the worst selling season in nine years. Many stores are packed with people, but many seem to be modern-day Scrooges and aren't buying much. Christmas sales are patchy. A last-minute flurry of purchases is expected, but this won't salvage the crucial season, experts say. ``The vote on this Christmas will be that it was a very poor Christmas,'' said Nick Bubb, a retail analyst with the investment firm Morgan Stanley International in London. ``It's going to be flat.'' The disappointing pre-Christmas season has prompted many stores to start slashing prices before Britain's traditional January sales. Many also likely will defy the law requiring them to close on Sundays and risk a fine of $1,600 to stay open on the day before Christmas. The poor sales trend reflects a months-long downturn, and it's bad news for retailers' profits, and their stock prices, which generally have been depressed on London's Stock Exchange. But it's good news for consumers, who are benefiting from sales in jewelry, consumer electronics, clothing and home furnishings. It's also positive for Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's Conservative government because slower sales are a sign that its anti-inflation policy is working. ``It's been a bad year. Christmas will make or break some people,'' said Harry Shepherd, director of the Oxford Street Association. Oxford Street is London's main shopping street. Shepherd said he expects retailers to eke out an overall 1 percent to 2 percent sales gain, but that won't be enough to cover higher costs. ``The Tiffanies of the world appear to be doing OK on the basis that the very rich will always be rich and the retailers selling three pairs of knickers for 99 pence are still doing very well. It's the mass in the middle who are suffering,'' he said. Consumer electronics and furniture retailers will be hurt the most, Bubb predicted. Experts agree that trading conditions are tough because of the higher interest rates, which the government has pushed to an eight-year peak to fight resurgent inflation. Inflation is running at an annual rate of 7.7 percent. The higher interest rates have squeezed British homeowners, who mostly hold adjustable rate mortgages and have seen their monthly payments climb sharply. Before the economy began overheating more than 18 months ago, Britain enjoyed a five-year, steady economic expansion fueled by consumer demand. But growth in consumer spending has slowed from 7 percent in 1988, to an expected 4 percent in 1989, and is predicted to slow to 1 percent in 1990. The slowdown has been showing up in the government's retail sales figures. In November, sales declined a sharp 0.8 percent from October, the government announced recently. That meant sales for the latest three months rose 1.1 percent over a year ago, the lowest such growth rate since June 1982, figures from the Central Statistical Office show. The retailers themselves are having to pay the higher interest rates, and rents are pricey too. Wage costs also are up because fewer teenage workers are available. Although the inflation rate is high, retailers can't raise prices to enhance their profits, Bubb said. Their promotions aren't going to help the bottom line. Ratners jewelry stores, for example, are offering the equivalent of $80 gift vouchers for every $240 worth of sales, while the Tandy consumer electronics chain has slashed $8 off a radio cassette player to $48. The longer-term outlook is gloomy too. The Confederation of British Industry, the country's major business group, recently said one of its regular surveys showed that retailers and wholesalers anticipate a deterioration in business over the coming three months. It was the first time since the survey was launched in 1983 that such a decline was expected.
